title: Scripts for navigating difficult conversations | Alisa Cohn (executive coach)
key_insights: Use scripts and structured approaches to make difficult conversations less daunting and more effective
Focus on observable facts rather than judgments when giving performance feedback
A leader's job is not to make employees happy, but to create conditions for winning and success
End every meeting with three questions: What did we decide? Who needs to do what by when? Who else needs to know?
Co-founders should discuss values, vision, conflict resolution styles, and company culture before starting a business together
When someone gets defensive during feedback, pause the conversation and remind them why the feedback helps their career
Hope for the future is essential when delivering disappointing news like promotion denials
Building relationships through positive feedback creates a foundation for difficult conversations later
topics_discussed: Three questions to end meetings effectively
Why leaders shouldn't focus on making employees happy
Process vs. patience in leadership decisions
memorable_quotes: Hope for the future is so important. I know this is going to be challenging for you to hear, not going to promote you, but I want you to know this. It's really important to me that you're able to succeed in your career here.
If you can see your path all the way through to the end, you are following someone else's path. Your path only becomes clear moment by moment as each foot hits the ground.
65% of startups fail because of conflict with founders or the founding team.
recommended_for: people who struggle with difficult conversations
summary: Executive coach Alisa Cohn provides specific scripts and frameworks for having difficult conversations, running effective meetings, and building strong founder relationships. The episode offers practical, actionable advice for leaders who want to improve their communication skills and create winning cultures rather than just trying to keep employees happy.
